comments.commentBody: Grand Budapest Hotel?
Now we have to put up with 10 months of studios putting out mediocre movies until the awards season starts. Because nobody remembers a movie that comes out in March.

As someone responsible for hiring PhD level scientists and engineers I'd welcome the opportunity to hire American citizens. Sadly, all to often the only candidates qualified are foreign citizens - usually educated at American Universities. $ 100k starting salaries apparently arent enough to entice US citizens to do the necessary studying.

Cara,
What a wonderful job you did. And I suspect only current and former New York Times folks understand that trying to be David Carr must have weighed heavy from the start but felt lie a stone on your chest after his death. That makes you both hugely talented and hugely brave.

I agree with Stu Freeman's comments, we need more of this!

Thanks for the great coverage.
The Capitol police also like to hassle dog owners that let their dogs run off leash on the Capitol grounds and chase little kids who dare ride their sleighs down the Capitol hills.

Maybe if the Capitol police start overlooking minor marijuana charges they'll have more time to start enforcing more drunk driving charges against many of our elected officials who feel they unoficially deserve special dispensation from such criminal activity. Leave the people of D.C. alone. They have no representation of any meaningful consequence.
It would in all probability be a good development for all of us if D.C. became the American Amsterdam.

The Republicans don't know if they are comming or going on this issue. I thought they were against nanny-state intrusions into adult's living their lives, and federal overreach into local issues? Talk about blatant hypocrisy! The residents of D.C. should ignore the empty threats and grandstanding by these guys, and remind them that they are in their city to fix the nation's problems, not create new ones.

Hmmm... Congress apparently can't pass a bill to fund Homeland Security but can certainly spend a great deal of time worrying about marijuana in D.C. It's good to know that once again they have their priorities straight. I'm sure the constituency in Utah feels better knowing that their elected official is keeping the country safe from pot smokers in the nation's capitol.

Nobody should drive while impaired on anything, and the impaired should be arrested.

THC doubtless affects driving at higher levels, but most cannabis consumers don't drive under impairing levels. THC effects diminish much faster than with alcohol, so its easier for driver to abstain before driving. Colorado highway fatalities actually decreased after legalization.

The recent study by the NHTSA of 3000 traffic fatalities in Virginia Beach "did not find an increase in population-based crash risk associated with THC use" but found that alcohol increase accident risk by 4-12 times. Texting is probably even more dangerous than drinking.
Holland is not Socialist. In fact, it's one of the most capitalistic countries on earth, and has been since the 1400s.

Correct.
Unless you're a woman or one of 700,000 non violent drug offenders languishing in a corporate run prison. Remember, the freedom of choice is yours until an old, mainly white man decides your freedom needs to be curbed on a specific issue they either don't understand or their religious/financial patron has registered an objection.
Don't be silly. Don't you know that for the GOP getting the government off our backs only applies to the 2nd Amendment and oversight over corporations?
I thought Conservatism was all about freedom of choice and non-interference in the choices made by and lives of Americans?

The people have spoken on this issue, their decision is final
------------------------
In D. C. it's not. The vote they had lacks any grounds, or legality, to change existing Federal law. Only Congress can do that.
I've been using it medically since 1996, with an ID card, etc.  You're dreaming if you think it's such a panacea.  One Vicodin is worth 2 joints, any day.

Did Los Angelenos enjoy it when Holder's DA got all 4 US Attorneys in Calif. to swear to close the pot dispensaries 3 years ago?  In all of Los Angeles and San Diego counties, they all closed.  A handful continued with delivery service only.  Not the GOP's doing at all.  Unlike conservative LA and San Diego, the Bay Area shops refused to close, BTW.

I say make all drugs legal, educate people, take away crime.  Wake up Republicans this is 2015 and the people of D.C. have spoken.  If anything should be regulated it should be booze and all cars should have a breathalizer interface on the ignition to keep drunk drivers off the road.  Those under the influence of marijuana know better.

I think the best part of this news is that the Republican push to ban municipal broadband across the country (quid pro quo for campaign contributions, if any lawyers are paying attention) is now over.  The first shoots of competition will be in Chattanooga, TN and Wilson, NC, where their bans have now been overturned today as well.  As for the rest?  Its over.  So much for the party that champions 'competition', eh?  The only competition Republicans promote is among their donors, for the highest contributions.

Verizon, AT&T and Comcast aren't, strictly speaking, ISP's, though they do provide ISP services that compete with regular ISP's (some would argue unfairly, hence the call for net neutrality).  They are telco's, ie more than just internet providers.  Unlike most ISP's they own the largest pipes (backbone) that create the American internet, in addition to the older copper wire that (continue to) provide phone as well as cable services in addition to the internet that can be pushed through that same copper.

ISP's aren't telco's.  The telco's are required to 'share the pipe' for ISP's to conduct their business, and now, thanks to the recent FCC ruling, they'll have a regulator on their side making sure they and their business aren't discriminated against by the telco's who (more often than not) own the pipe as well as provide their own ISP-like services.

"much of the slowness is caused not by broadband networks but by browsers, websites and high usage." Richard Bennett, AEI

Omg. That is the lamest excuse I've heard yet to argue against FCC-fostered competition. As if the rest of the world is using different browsers, different network gear, different codecs, and different code. Heck, a lot of it is American tech! What is he saying, that Americans are the ones who don't know how to use there own tech properly? Really?

I am so sick and tired of being taken for a fool by these 'conservative' blowhards.

People who vote Republican (and the birds so elected) want our lives to be controlled by the "free market." Well, we just dodged, courtesy of the non-Republican FCC directors (and make no mistake, just for the time being), a significant consequence of that "free" market. The FCC's 3-2 vote, of course, still doesn't fix the monopolistic cable and satellite industry, who continue to gouge their customers at will.

Anyone who is less than wealthy and votes Republican these days is hurting us all.

Quite frankly I get better internet service both "landline" and "cell" for less money when I travel in Slovakia or Romania than here in the US! Here I have one choice of internet provider (unless I use DSL) and pay handsomely for any "real" speed! Internet has become a MONOPOLY pure and simple, and because of this offer crappy service at a high cost. Im holding my verdict on "net neutrality" because it seems that at this point big business "owns" Washington anyway.
My personal opinion is that coax and fiber be just like a pipeline. One company owns the media but are required to carry the "content and services" of all "carriers" at a fixed price.
@michael t johnson:  Yeah, the Brits pay $8 a gallon and we pay $3....and I wonder what their roads are like.  I would bet you they are much better than ours - at least in my state of Maine.

Marijuana use, perhaps.  But I'm sure there have been one or two deaths by gunshot or stabbing over the years relating to marijuana dealing.  Fortunately, legalization will likely reduce/remove that possibility too.

Both Jennifewriter and Kookula are correct I'd say, except that there was also apparently a marijuana related death in Nebraska in 1996, when a marijuana farmhand inadvertently tipped a 500 pound bale onto himself.  But overall, there are way less deaths from marijuana than from alcohol or toothpicks.  Lots of people still choke on toothpicks, don't think we can legislate that away though.
Defending marijuana on medical grounds when the debate has shifted to the merits of full legalization does not help.

Not one death has ever been attributed to marijuana.

On Jan. 1, Arizona became the 10th state to allow for the use of marijuana for the treatment of PTSD.

Ask any parent of a child with Dravet's Syndrome what they think about marijuana.

The Journal of the American Medical Association last year published an article stating that in states with medical marijuana, overdose deaths from legal painkillers was 10 percent to 25 percent lower than in states without medical marijuana (it made no link between correlation and causation).

Those are just a few of the facts off the top of my head. Grow up, America, and let's have an adult conversation about marijuana.

It sounds more and more, with each passing day, that the fix is in - for the GOP, the third strike - er, candidate, from that dodgiest of dynasties, the Bushes. And for the Dems, the Clinton who never got into trouble with a cigar. (With a bad health plan, yes, but that was 'close, but no cigar'.) In other words, it's Wall Street vs Wall Street. Guess who's going to win. And the rest of us? How does a third class passage sound - on RMS Titanic?
Christie is a joke. Jeb Bush has picked advisors that nail him to the Iraq War. And Cruz and Walker are to the right of Goldwater. They may have to draft Romney.
I wouldn't take that to the bank.  Jeb v. Hillary will be excruciating for the entire country, an ugly Bush v Gore redux.
